Trial_Design.evidence: Patients were divided into two groups based on whether they received a transversus abdominis plane (TAP) block.

Participants.evidence: A consecutive series of 100 patients who underwent kidney transplant was reviewed.

Intervention.evidence: Group A consisted of patients who received an ultrasound-guided TAP block, while Group B included patients who did not receive any form of TAP block.

Objective.evidence: We aim to review our current clinical practice of peri-operative use of regional blocks during kidney transplants and management of peri-operative pain up to 24 h.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The intra-operative and post-operative use of analgesia was recorded for up to 24 h post kidney transplant.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 100 patients were identified and equally distributed between the two groups [Group A = 50 (TAP block), Group B = 50 (non-TAP block)].

Number_Analysed.evidence: A total of 100 patients were identified and equally distributed between the two groups [Group A = 50 (TAP block), Group B = 50 (non-TAP block)].

Result_Outcome.evidence: There was a statistically significant reduction in the use of intraoperative fentanyl ( p = 0.04) in Group A.

Harms.evidence: There were no complications recorded secondary to the use of regional blocks in Group A.
